notes: One of the most widely recognized gematria values. The custom of giving monetary gifts in multiples of 18 derives from this equivalence.
Composed of the first, middle, and last letters of the Hebrew alphabet (aleph, mem, tav), symbolizing that truth spans from beginning to end.
Shares its gematria value (13) with ahavah (love). This is frequently cited in connection with the Shema prayer: 'Hear O Israel, the Lord our God, the Lord is One.'
Equals echad (one) at 13, teaching that love and unity are connected. Together they sum to 26, the value of the Tetragrammaton (YHVH).
The most sacred name of God. Its gematria value of 26 is among the most frequently referenced in Jewish numerology.
Shares its value of 358 with nachash (serpent), a connection explored extensively in kabbalistic literature (see Genesis 3 and the concept of rectification).
Equals mashiach (messiah) at 358. Kabbalistic teaching holds that the messiah rectifies the damage caused by the serpent in the Garden of Eden.
The Talmud notes that Moses transmitted 611 commandments, and two more were heard directly from God, totaling 613.
Shares its value of 70 with sod (secret), giving rise to the Talmudic saying: 'When wine enters, secrets come out' (nichnas yayin yatza sod).
Shares its value of 70 with yayin (wine). The word also denotes the deepest level of Torah interpretation in the PaRDeS system.

meaning: God (divine name associated with judgment and nature)
notes: Shares its value of 86 with ha-teva (the nature), teaching that God's presence is embedded within the natural world.
Equals Elohim (86). This equivalence, cited by the Vilna Gaon and others, is taken to mean that nature is a manifestation of divine power.
Chokhmah is the second of the ten Sefirot (divine emanations) in Kabbalistic thought, representing the first flash of intellectual insight.
Sarah's name was changed from Sarai (שרי, value 510) to Sarah (שרה, value 505) by God in Genesis 17:15.
Shares its value of 345 with El Shaddai (אל שדי), one of the names of God, a connection noted in traditional commentaries.
The opening word of the Shema, the central declaration of Jewish faith. Also equals the numerical value of kadosh (holy, קדוש = 410).
Shares its value of 44 with yeled (ילד, child), connecting the concepts of blood and progeny in traditional interpretation.
